skill.name: defi-mev-battletest
skill.description: Expert knowledge for DeFi/MEV bot development including critical pitfalls, backtesting realities, AMM mechanics, MEV extraction strategies, and production failure modes
skill.summary: Expert knowledge for DeFi/MEV bot development including critical pitfalls, backtesting realities, AM...
skill.author: BarisSozen

security_audit.summary: Pure educational skill containing only markdown documentation and TypeScript code examples for DeFi/MEV trading patterns. No executable code, scripts, network calls, or filesystem access detected. All 107 static findings are false positives caused by scanner misinterpretation of markdown formatting and legitimate blockchain terminology.

content.user_title: Build DeFi Bots Without Costly Mistakes
content.value_statement: DeFi trading bots fail in production due to hidden risks that backtests miss. This skill embeds battle-tested patterns from real failures so you can avoid catastrophic losses when building arbitrage, MEV, or automated trading strategies.
actual_capabilities: Identify hidden risks in arbitrage opportunities including reorg, gas spikes, and latency
Calculate realistic expected value accounting for failure rates and competition
Implement Uniswap V3 tick mechanics and concentrated liquidity handling
Configure Flashbots bundle submission with proper simulation and privacy
Apply MEV-Share patterns for backrunning with profit sharing
Design kill switches and circuit breakers for automated trading systems
limitations: Does not execute trades or connect to blockchain networks directly
Does not provide real-time market data or price feeds
Cannot replace testing with actual simulation before going live
References external services but does not implement connectivity

use_cases.title: Build Safe Trading Bots
use_cases.description: Learn critical pitfalls before your bot loses money on reorgs, sandwich attacks, or gas spikes.

use_cases.title: Model MEV Economics
use_cases.description: Calculate true expected value with realistic failure rates and competition models.

use_cases.title: Integrate Flashbots
use_cases.description: Implement private orderflow and bundle submission correctly with production patterns.

prompt_templates.title: Check Arbitrage Safety
prompt_templates.prompt: Use the DeFi MEV skill to analyze this arbitrage opportunity. What are the hidden risks I should consider? Calculate the realistic expected value accounting for failure rate, reorg probability, and gas costs.

prompt_templates.title: Implement Flashbots Bundle
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me the correct pattern for Flashbots bundle submission including simulation, gas configuration, and coinbase payment for competitive bidding.

prompt_templates.title: Calculate Price Impact
prompt_templates.prompt: Explain the Uniswap V3 price impact formula for concentrated liquidity. How do I calculate slippage when crossing multiple ticks with different liquidity depths?

prompt_templates.title: Design Kill Switch
prompt_templates.scenario: Adding safety limits to trading bot
prompt_templates.prompt: What are the non-negotiable kill switch requirements for a production trading bot? Include circuit breaker thresholds, automatic triggers, and manual override patterns.

output_examples.input: Analyze this arbitrage: buy ETH on Uniswap V2 at 2000 USDC, sell on Curve stETH pool at 2010 USDC, expected profit 10 USDC per ETH
output: CRITICAL RISKS:
Curve stETH pool may have depeg risk during market stress
stETH liquidity concentrated - may not have depth for your trade size
30 percent failure rate realistic for cross-protocol arb
2 percent reorg rate means some profitable txs will be uncle'd
REALISTIC EV CALCULATION:
Gross profit: 10 dollars
Gas on success: 5 to 8 dollars for cross-chain swap
Gas on failure: still pays 5 to 8 dollars
Expected value: zero point six eight times two minus zero point three times six equals negative zero point four four
This 10 dollar opportunity is likely unprofitable
RECOMMENDATION: Skip this arb or increase trade size significantly.

output_examples.input: How do I set up private transaction submission to avoid front-running?
output: USE PRIVATE ORDERFLOW:
Never use public mempool for arbitrage transactions
Flashbots Protect: protect.flashbots.net - free basic protection
MEV-Blocker: rpc.mevblocker.io - good free option
BUNDLE SUBMISSION:
Use Flashbots relay for competitive strategies
Include coinbase payment for stealthy bidding
Simulate before submitting to verify profitability
MEV-SHARE:
Required for some orderflow
Share 50 to 90 percent of profits with users
Backrun-only strategy with limited information

best_practices: Always simulate against pending state, not historical blocks, to match production conditions
Factor in 20 to 30 percent failure rate and 1 to 2 percent reorg rate when calculating expected value
Implement kill switch with capital limits before deploying any trading strategy
anti_patterns: Trusting backtest results without adjusting for latency, gas prediction, and competition
Using public mempool for arbitrage transactions - you will be front-run
Setting slippage too high or too low without understanding liquidity distribution
Deploying without testing on a forked mainnet with realistic conditions first

faq.question: Does this skill connect to blockchain networks?
faq.answer: No. This skill provides knowledge and patterns only. You implement connectivity using standard Web3 libraries in your own code.

faq.question: What failure rates should I assume for arbitrage?
faq.answer: Conservative estimates are 30 percent failure rate for cross-protocol trades and 1 to 2 percent reorg rate on Ethereum mainnet.

faq.question: How does this skill integrate with my existing bot?
faq.answer: Use it during design and development. Prompt for best practices, review patterns, and validate your architecture before implementation.

faq.question: Is my trading data safe?
faq.answer: Yes. This skill only provides guidance. No data leaves your environment and no external connections are made.

faq.question: Why do backtests lie about profitability?
faq.answer: Backtests use perfect historical state. Production has latency, mempool competition, gas uncertainty, and reorgs that historical data cannot capture.

faq.question: How is this different from reading documentation?
faq.answer: This skill embeds hard-won lessons from production failures. Documentation tells you how things work. This tells you what breaks in practice.
